content: The Act may be cited as the "Tar Creek Restoration Act". It includes findings related to the restoration efforts. The Tar Creek Superfund Site in Ottawa County, Oklahoma, was a lead and zinc mining area from the early 1900s to the 1970s. It is part of the Tri-State Mining District and is prone to flooding due to its location. Mining companies had to pump water from the Boone Aquifer. The Tar Creek Superfund Site in Oklahoma, part of the Tri-State Mining District, was a lead and zinc mining area from the early 1900s to the 1970s. Mining companies had to pump water from the Boone Aquifer, and much of the mining was on Indian land controlled by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. During World War I, mining at the Site accounted for over 45% of the Nation's wartime consumption. During World War II, the Department of the Interior recommended stockpiling waste tailings aboveground at the Tar Creek Superfund Site for later reprocessing. In 1960, Congress enacted the Small Producers Lead and Zinc Mining Stabilization Act to encourage lead and zinc production at the Site. In 1979, acid mine water began discharging at the surface from several locations at the Site as the underground mine workings refilled with water from the Boone Aquifer. In 1983, the Site was placed on the National Priorities List due to acid mine water discharging at the surface from underground mine workings refilled with water from the Boone Aquifer. In 1984, the Environmental Protection Agency started remediation efforts for the acid mine water. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will provide assistance under the Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property Acquisition Policies Act of 1970 to residents in the 17 square mile area identified in Governor Keating's Tar Creek Superfund Task Force Final Report. This includes the communities of Picher and Cardin on the Tar Creek Superfund site in Oklahoma. The EPA will be considered the displacing agency for the application of the Act. The Environmental Protection Agency will provide assistance to residents in the Tar Creek Superfund site in Oklahoma under the Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property Acquisition Policies Act of 1970. The EPA will work with other officials to seek a comprehensive resolution for the cleanup of the site. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will collaborate with other officials to address environmental and health issues at the Tar Creek Superfund site, without relieving any agency of cleanup responsibilities under the law.
